publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: The converted Iew or Certaine dialogues betweene Michæas a learned Iew, and others, touching diuers points of religion, controuerted betweene the Catholicks and Protestants. Written by M. Iohn Clare a Catholicke priest, of the Society of Iesus. Dedicated to the two Vniuersities of Oxford and Cambridge
monogr.author: Clare, John

div.head: The Interlocutours of euery Dialogue.
div.p: 1. In the first Dialogue is disputed; whether the Church of Rome hath made any change in fayth and Religion, since the first plantation of it by the Apostles? It is proued, that it hath not.

q.p: Ad Romanos perfidia non potest habere accessum.

div.p: 2. In the second Dialogue, entituled: The second part of the Conuerted Iew, is discussed; whether in euery age since the Apostles; or rather whether but in any one Age sin • e that tyme, till Luthers dayes, there can be giuen any Instances of Professours of Protestancy? It is proued, that no such Instances can be giuen.

list.item: Ochinus, who first planted Protestancy in England, in King
Neuserus, Chiefe Pastour of Heidelberg, in the Palatinat.

q.p: Si dixerint vobis: Ecce in deserto est; nolite exire. Ecce in penetratibus; nolite credere.

div.p: 3. In the third and last Dialogue, styled: The arraingnment of the Conuerted Iew. It is discoursed; Whether the Protestants of the Catholiks, do stand more chargeable, with disloyalty to their lawfull Princes? It is proued, that the Protestants stand more chargeable. In this last dialogue, are diuers other points of Catholike Religion breifly handled.

list.item: The right Honourable the Lord Cheife Iustice of England.

q.p: Vidi mulierem, ebriam de sanguine Sanctorum.
